metatags.twitter:title: WATCH: A McDonald's Big Mac Is "Indestructible" When Covered in Molten Copper
metatags.author: Bec Crew
metatags.og:title: WATCH: A McDonald's Big Mac Is "Indestructible" When Covered in Molten Copper
metatags.og:description: In footage that looks like the culinary version of Viserys' famously gruesome death scene in Game of Thrones, YouTuber Tito4re is seen pouring molten copper over a McDonald's Big Mac.
metatags.twitter:creator: @ScienceAlert
metatags.viewport: width=device-width, initial-scale=1, shrink-to-fit=no, maximum-scale=12.0, minimum-scale=.25, user-scalable=yes
metatags.twitter:description: But science says that’s what *every* burger bun should do.

website_content.content:
width="700″ height="414″ allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" seamless="seamless">
In footage that looks like the culinary version of Viserys'  in _Game of Thrones_,  is seen pouring molten copper over a McDonald's Big Mac. Experimenting on McDonald's products to show how indestructible and indigestible they are , but in this case, you can blame science, not the burger, for these puzzling results.
 shows that as soon as the molten copper makes contact with the burger bun, it starts to ball up and roll off the surface.
And while the top of the bun is well and truly burnt by the end of it, we're shown that the rest of the burger underneath is completely fine - the molten copper didn't get even close to melting through the surface of the bread. Buns of steel!
We also see a similar effect on the burger patty when it's directly exposed to the molten copper, and just so you know, that copper is heated to around 1,093 degrees Celsius (2,000 degrees Fahrenheit).
Pretty nuts, right? Well no, not at all, if you know your basic physics.
, the video footage is real, but the implications that Big Macs are bad specifically because they don't melt from molten copper exposure are false. "In fact, the results showcased in this video (just like experiments with seemingly non-rotting hamburgers) could likely be replicated with any burger (or similar food item), regardless of brand," 
The phenomenon that's being demonstrated here isn't terrible food, it's the , which we last saw in  of molten salt being added to water.
You can also see the Leidenfrost effect in action , where molten copper is poured into water, , where it forces water into an amazing star shape on a hot surface.
The Leidenfrost effect is defined in physics as when a liquid comes in contact with a mass that's significantly hotter than its boiling point, and produces an insulating vapour layer that protects the liquid from boiling and evaporating away immediately.
You've probably seen it in cooking when you get drops of water on a really hot pan - the water balls up and skids across the surface, protected by a layer of water vapour.
So in the case of the Big Mac, some of the moisture in the burger bun boils when it comes into contact with the molten copper, and this produces a strong, insulating layer that initially protects it.
, the guys from Mythbusters demonstrated this effect in 2009 by showing that you could dip your hand into molten lead without getting burned:
width="700″ height="414″ allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" seamless="seamless">
Still though, do _not_...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: ScienceAlert is recognized for its publishing of scientific news and studies. The information is typically fact-checked and backed by scientific literature. The site has a reputation for accuracy, although it may sometimes prioritize sensational headlines to attract readership. Overall, its strong grounding in scientific credibility lends it a high-quality score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence comes from a credible science-focused website and discusses the experiment shown in the viral video. It explains the Leidenfrost effect observed when molten copper is poured over the Big Mac, clarifying that the 'indestructibility' of the burger is a result of physical principles rather than properties of the food itself. This directly addresses the claim's assumption of indestructibility and provides scientific reasoning that counteracts it.

Six-Month-Old McDonald's Happy Meal Is Indestructible
=====================================================
by  Oct 13, 2010, 10:30am EDT
Share this story
----------------
*   
*   
*   
### **Share** All sharing options for: Six-Month-Old McDonald's Happy Meal Is Indestructible
*   
*   
*   
 !/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/39229432/sally-davies-happy-meal.0.jpg)
A six-month-old Happy Meal.
Photo: 
New York artist **Sally Davies** bought a Happy Meal from **McDonald's** in April and  of it periodically over the past six months — just to see how much it changed over time. Problem is, it didn't change much. Sure, the burger shrank some, and the fries look a little shriveled, but **no mold, no sign of decay**. McDonald's  saying they couldn't respond to the project because they were unsure what condition the burger and fries were kept in; we suppose they're alluding to the possibility that they were frozen? Or stored in the vacuum that is outer space? Watch the video below and decide for yourself.
**Video: Happy Meal Mold-Free After Six Months**

evidence2.title: Icelandic man keeps McDonald's burger and fries in glass case for ...

evidence2.snippet: Nov 4, 2019 ... The so-called “indestructible*” McDonald's meal has no sign of mould or decay. Back in 2009, McDonald's closed down all three of its restaurants ...
evidence2.htmlSnippet: Nov 4, 2019 ... The so-called “indestructible*” McDonald's meal has no sign of mould or decay. Back in 2009, McDonald's closed down all three of its restaurants ...

website_content.content:
READING LEVEL: GREEN
A McDonald’s fan has kept a burger and fries in a glass cabinet for 10 years – and it still looks fine to eat.
The so-called “indestructible\*” McDonald’s meal has no sign of mould or decay.
Back in 2009, McDonald’s closed down all three of its restaurants in Iceland.
One man decided to buy the country’s final hamburger and fries – so the meal could live on after the chain’s closure.
“I had heard that McDonald’s never decompose\* so I just wanted to see if it was true or not,” Hjortur Smarason said.
It’s now been exactly 10 years since Smarason made his purchase, and the meal barely looks older.
The not-so-happy meal is housed in a glass cabinet in Snotra House, a hostel\* in southern Iceland.
“The old guy is still there, feeling quite well,” said hostel owner Siggi Sigurdur, speaking to BBC News.
“It’s a fun thing, of course, but it makes you think about what you are eating.
“There is no mould, it’s only the paper wrapping that looks old.”
The hostel says that people visit from around the world to see the burger.
And a livestream of the meal receives up to 400,000 hits every single day.
The meal hasn’t always been kept in a glass cabinet, however.
At first, Smarason stored the burger and fries in a plastic bag in...[Content truncated]

website_content.content:
The indestructible burger. - kmkat and her kneedles
===============          
===========================================================================
Knitting, stuff, other stuff, and some more knitting
----------------------------------------------------
 |  | 
07 November 2010
----------------
### The indestructible burger.
]
We have all read or heard about the McDonald's hamburger that would neither mold nor rot nor decompose in any significant way, supposedly showing how little food value actually exists in one. _Real food wouldn't act like that, right?_
, a food writer discourses on the subject.
_"The problem with all of these tests is that there is but a single data point, and a single data point is about as useless as a one armed man in a clapping contest. Who knows why those burgers didn't decompose?...__Without experimentation, there is no science. Without science, there is no proof. Without proof, there is no truth, and without truth, well where would we be?...It seems to me that the only thing that can last longer than a McDonald's hamburger is an internet meme about them. My project for the next few weeks: design and carry out the first well-documented, scientific experiment to shed some light on whether or not there is something truly evil lurking between the buns._"
In order to reach the truth he designs his own controlled experiment, comparing:
1.  A plain McDonald's hamburger, stored on a plate at room temperature.
2.  A homemade burger of the same weight and dimensions as a McDonald's burger. (using a store-bought bun because who bakes their own buns?)
3.  A McDonald's hamburger patty on a store-bought bun.
4.  A homemade patty on a McDonald's bun.
5.  A McDonald's hamburger stored in its original packaging.
6.  A McDonald's hamburger stored in a zipper-lock bag.
7.  A plain Quarter Pounder.
8.  A homemade quarter pounder.
The  are.. _surprising_. And, to those of us who rather like sensational results and...[Content truncated]

website_content.content:
Advertisement
Supported by
Virtually indestructible, these artificial compounds are used in fast-food packaging and countless household items, but they have been found as far away as virgin forests.
By Isabella Grullón Paz
Based on nothing more than their name, per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances certainly don’t sound like something you’d want to find in your burger wrapper. But according to a recent investigation by Consumer Reports, they’re very much there — as well as in your salad bowl, fry bag and sandwich wrap.
So what are these virtually indestructible compounds, created in a lab in 1938 by a 27-year-old chemist? And how worried do you need to be about them?
This is what you should know about PFAS.
As one researcher put it: “everywhere.”
PFAS are in your shampoo bottle, your stain-resistant couch, your dental floss, your bicycle lubricant. And when these multipurpose compounds are used in food packaging, they have a way of transferring to the food itself. To say that PFAS are difficult to avoid is an understatement.
Although these substances have been in use for eight decades, regulators have only recently acquired the scientific understanding and technical capacity needed to test for them at the very low concentrations — measured in parts per trillion — at which they’re present in food, according to the Food and Drug Administration.
In light of those advances, the F.D.A. recommends not reading too much into the fact that a given product might have “detectable” levels of the chemicals. “Even when there have been detectable levels of PFAS,” the agency said, “our safety assessments have shown no cause for avoiding these foods.”

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]...s burgers are prepared in a way that “removes excess moisture” … which I interpret as meaning “they’re dryer than the Sahara” and McMummyBurgers are only REALLY tasty when they’re within the golden hour of their entombment in the Plastic Mummy Case.
McDonalds meat patties (at least in America) begin with force-fattened young cattle which are kept in rather stressful conditions and fed food that causes their guts to be damaged. They deal with this by giving them corrective doses of antibiotics and certain steroids that keep them gaining rather than losing muscle. Then they’re quick-slaughtered, parted out in as sanitary a set of conditions as they can achieve for the price (because rotting meat cannot be sold) and then super-fast frozen. They’re thawed just enough to complete the removal of meat from bones, and turned into various forms of ground beef, still at very low temperature. Then, the burgers themselves are formed and frozen. The temperatures at which they’re frozen and packed and kept will stun or kill most decay bacteria.
Then, they’re transported in refrigerated trucks to the individual franchised stores. There, they defrost them enough to be cooked, and when they do cook them, it’s quick but complete. There is no such thing as a rare McBurger. Any excess water that hasn’t been freeze-dried off the outside, is sweated out during the process of cooking the meat to well-done.
Note that the cooks all have to meet sanitary requirements, so as not to contaminate the burgers.  
They then put them on their various vessels of bread with oily sauces, vegetables, and oh yes the tomatoes are kept from touching the meat. They’re placed in their final resting boxes and kept under heat lamps.
They’re kept at the legally mandated holding temperature, and if they aren’t sold within an hour or two they are thrown away. Discarded. This is because (1) they taste unhappy and we can’t have that in any happy meal, and (2) they might grow bacteria.
Once delivered into the hands of their customers, it’s expected that they will be eaten within a few minutes. An hour at most. So they’ll still be edible and taste exactly like a McBurger.
Back in college, my then-future wife made a movie for a class she needed … and it involved googly eyes attached to fast food and was shot with an 8mm camera.
The story of an ordinary McDonalds burger which became aware of its existence, and became Cosmically McWare (1). It knew its purpose, to be eaten...[Content truncated]

While informative, it does not address the qualities of the food in the context of the video or the claim of indestructibility, resulting in a lower relevance score.

Response to myth that McDonald’s burgers do not decompose
=========================================================
August 31, 2020
In the right environment, our burgers, like most other foods, could decompose.
But, in order to decompose, you need certain conditions – specifically moisture. Without sufficient moisture – either in the food itself or the environment – bacteria and mold may not grow and therefore, decomposition is unlikely. So if food is or becomes dry enough, it is unlikely to grow mold or bacteria or decompose.  Food prepared at home that is left to dehydrate could see similar results. Look closely, the burgers you are seeing are likely dried out and dehydrated, and by no means “the same as the day they were purchased.”
The reality is that our burgers are made only with 100% USDA inspected beef. There are  and the only thing ever added is a touch of salt and pepper on the grill.

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This is the official corporate website for McDonald's, providing information about their policies, products, and values. While it is a credible source for facts about the company, it may present information in a way that favors its public image. Thus, it can still serve as a reliable source for corporate-related inquiries.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides a direct response from McDonald's to myths about their burgers not decomposing. It presents a straightforward explanation about the conditions necessary for food decomposition, helping to debunk the claim of indestructibility while emphasizing that food can decompose under the right conditions. Its relevance lies in addressing misconceptions directly related to the claim.

I would not take a chance on them if I didn’t know how old they were.
I depends on how long they have been sitting around and where they were stored. It might not hurt you, but they probably wouldn’t taste very good.

Related
Let's say there's a zombie apocalypse, how long can the old McDonald's burgers and fries sit there and still be edible?
As long as any other food. McDonalds food being indestructible and won’t rot is a myth and depends a lot on the conditions. McDonalds meat will be inedible if it’s left out for more than a few hours, the same way any meat will spoil.
Some of this may depend on where you are. McDonalds often sources it’s food locally, here in Ireland they use Irish beef and Irish potatoes because we can produce those two things pretty cheaply and Irish consumers won’t eat anything but Irish meat and potatoes. Our meat is of a universally high standard, we can’t make bad meat products, we have very high food stan
